docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc. said today that it had earned $288 million in the second quarter in contrast to a loss of $297 million in the corresponding period last year. Aetna's turnaround was driven mostly by the sale of the company's property-casualty operations to the Travelers Group Inc.

headline.main: Aetna Shows A Comeback In Quarter

docs.lead_paragraph: Under court order, the private corporations set up to pay for Gov. George E. Pataki's elaborate inauguration and transition released records today showing that they had raised $2.5 million during the six months after his election, more than twice as much as the Pataki administration had previously claimed. The records show that much of the money came from health care, telecommunications, insurance and manufacturing companies that are regulated by state agencies or are seeking state contracts. Taking advantage of a loophole in state election laws, many of those companies contributed $10,000 or more to the postelection corporations or funds, significantly more than the $5,000 limit on what they could have contributed directly to Mr. Pataki's campaign.

headline.main: Pataki's Records Show Double the Contributions Reported

docs.lead_paragraph: Two of the most powerful members of Congress announced tonight that they had solved the major problem blocking passage of legislation to make health insurance more readily available to millions of Americans. The agreement was announced by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, a co-sponsor of the legislation, and by Representative Bill Archer, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, which wrote much of the bill.

headline.main: DEAL IN CONGRESS GIVES HEALTH BILL A NEW MOMENTUM

docs.lead_paragraph: Above the spindly semi-issues of the 1996 campaign, overhauling the nation's welfare system stands tall, shadowing President Clinton's unmet 1992 promise to "end welfare as we know it" and the Republicans' claim that they know how to undo three decades of dependency run amok. For Mr. Clinton, the personal and political choices are unpalatable. Having twice vetoed Republican welfare proposals as too harsh on children, he is under enormous pressure to sign a third version, especially because he has gone out of his way to pronounce the measures approved by the House and Senate in recent days much improved.

headline.main: Clinton in a Box as a Welfare Bill Edges Closer

docs.lead_paragraph: Philips Electronics N.V. reported an unexpected second-quarter loss today as it took a charge of $454 million to pay for 6,000 job cuts worldwide in its consumer electronics division. Philips, Europe's largest electronics company, reported a loss of 456 million Dutch guilders, or $273 million, in the quarter.

headline.main: Philips Posts a Surprise Loss And Plans a 6,000-Job Cut

docs.lead_paragraph: Moody's Investors Service, one of the Wall Street firms that rates New York State's bonds, sharply criticized the new state budget today, saying it failed to solve the problem of recurring deficits and virtually insures long and bitter budget fights in the coming years. The report probably does not mean that Moody's will downgrade the state's bond rating, which is already the second lowest, after Louisiana, among the 40 states the firm reviews. But it almost certainly means that Moody's will not upgrade New York's rating soon.

headline.main: Wall Street Bond Rating Firm Faults New York Budget

docs.snippet: Moody's Investors Service, one of the Wall Street firms that rates New York State's bonds, sharply criticized the new state budget today, saying it failed to solve the problem of recurring deficits and virtually insures long and bitter budget fights...

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton says he might sign welfare legislation if Congressional negotiators improve the House- and Senate-passed bills in a conference committee. He should stop shadow-boxing. The House's bill is odious. The Senate's is only slightly less so. The conferees will produce a compromise somewhere in between. That is not a place a Democratic President should stand. The conferees will hand the President a bill that, like the bills they will work from, will hurl more than a million children into poverty. It will slice food stamps by an average of $600 for families earning less than $6,300 a year. It will strip legal immigrants, including some elderly, of health insurance. It will, for the first time ever, tell workers who lose their jobs after years of steady work that they cannot collect food stamps for their children. President Clinton will find no honorable reason, in his own promises of welfare reform or the history of his party, to sign such a bill.

docs.lead_paragraph: Louie Pokrywka made a false start before bringing an elaborate schematic of the Kleenex production line to his computer screen. "Until a few weeks ago I hadn't sat down at a keyboard since high school typing class," apologized the line operator at Kimberly-Clark's paper products mill here. But his job is rapidly evolving from grunt work -- such as lifting boxes -- to the more demanding tasks of monitoring precision machinery. Mr. Pokrywka, one of the handful of employees who oversee the sophisticated robots that churn out Kleenex Pocket Packs, isn't feeling sorry for himself, though. And for good reason: he is on the right side of the invisible line dividing the industrial labor force into two camps -- a well-paid minority that tends machines and an unprivileged army of workers who, in effect, compete with them.

headline.main: Technology's Edict: Adapt Or Lose Out;Change Drives Growth, But Puts Labor at Risk
